image.altText: A man walks through journalists and cameras.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann has indicated he may appeal a Federal Court finding that on the balance of probabilities he raped Brittany Higgins.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann set to appeal Federal Court defamation judgment

image.altText: Bruce Lehrman leaves the Federal Court of Australia in Sydney 150424

props.synopsis: The Federal Court resumed to consider costs in Bruce Lehrmann's failed defamation case against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson. Look back at what happened in our live blog.

title.children: 'He has a great deal to lose': Court publishes Network Ten's 'walk away' letter to Lehrmann, as it happened

image.altText: Anthony Albanese with Micaela Cronin.

props.synopsis: At a national cabinet meeting addressing the gendered violence crisis, the federal government commits more than $900 million for a program supporting women leaving violence, and a suite of online measures to combat online misogyny and young people viewing pornography.

title.children: The government has committed $1bn to combat the violence against women crisis. Here's what we know

image.altText: People with suitcases using computer terminals at an airport with a Qantas sign behind them

props.synopsis: Qantas says its app is "stable and operating normally" after customers experienced ongoing issues hours after the airline said the glitch had been resolved, while the Australian share market ended lower. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas app 'operating normally' again for customers after earlier claiming issue had been 'resolved'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Qantas says app 'currently stable and operating normally'
ASX drops by 1.2pc at the close ahead of US interest rates meeting
Advice for Qantas customers from the information commissioner

image.altText: A Qantas jumbo takes off

props.synopsis: Qantas resolves an issue with its app that allowed customers to view the details of other passengers, including names and upcoming flight plans.

title.children: Qantas apologises after app shows passengers' information to other travellers

image.altText: Three riot police climb up a ramp to a building, a fourth police officer holds it down

props.synopsis: Student protests over the Israel-Gaza war expand to an increasing number of college campuses in the United States, with Australian students joining the camp-outs demanding that their educational institutions cut ties with Israel.

title.children: Riot police enter Columbia University to end pro-Palestinian encampment as movement takes hold in Australia

image.altText: Codie Bell, sexual assault victim

props.synopsis: A Canberra-based victim of alleged sexual assault calls for more support, after the Sexual Assault (Police) Review found the ACT had both the highest rate of sexual assault cases not proceeding to prosecution and the highest number of sexual assault victims withdrawing their complaints of any jurisdiction.

title.children: 'Clear something's not working': Sexual assault survivor calls for more victim support in the ACT following damning review

image.altText: A phone with the TikTok logo displayed.

props.synopsis: A Canberra grandmother escapes conviction for filming a video containing child abuse material of her granddaughter and posting it privately to social media platform TikTok, in a case ACT Supreme Court Justice Belinda Baker described as "highly unusual".

title.children: Canberra woman avoids jail for posting video of granddaughter identified as child abuse material by TikTok

image.altText: An illustration of a line of silhouetted people walking along a DNA spiral.

props.synopsis: Prenatal testing means some genetic conditions, like Down syndrome, can be identified in utero. But experts say it raises complex and challenging questions about how we value people with disabilities.

title.children: In Iceland, there are almost no babies born with Down syndrome. It's raised concerns from disability advocates

image.altText: A man wearing green and gold jersey clings to a boulder wall with two hands and a toe

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Top-ranked sports climber Campbell Harrison takes a break from training for the Paris Olympic Games to share how working from a young age to pursue his dream career has taught him the value of paying it forward.

title.children: Pay Day with Campbell Harrison: At the top of his sport, there's still 'not a lot of wiggle room'

image.altText: Jo Harten holds a netball in both hands

props.synopsis: Netball Australia is already embracing changes to their traditional playing dress, but the Super Netball clubs are yet to take up the offer. Giants co-captain Jo Harten says she is pushing hard to make it happen.

title.children: 'I'd be brave enough to change': Super Netball captain hoping to ditch the dress

image.altText: Two formally-dressed women walk next to each other with a man walking near them.

props.synopsis: Pauline Hanson's legal team tenders a video of her telling Derryn Hinch to leave Australia in her defence against allegations of racial discrimination against senator Mehreen Faruqi.

title.children: Video of Pauline Hanson telling white former senator to 'go back to New Zealand' used in racial discrimination defence

image.altText: a woman in a hospital bed taking a selfie

props.synopsis: Medical bills examined by experts reveals how Australian chronic pain sufferers are being apparently billed for fictitious services, inflated costs, and treatments for conditions they don't have.

title.children: 'I feel violated, I trusted them': Patients appalled after being shown the true nature of their medical bills

image.altText: Rubbish is strewn across the grass

props.synopsis: A pool lined with green sludge, rotting roofs and termite infested buildings – this derelict island resort has become a sad tourist attraction for all the wrong reasons, and it's not an isolated case.

title.children: Once a mecca for the rich and famous, these island resorts now lie in ruins

image.altText: Two men sit talking

props.synopsis: Chris Minns pays tribute to his father, the man he has previously said introduced him to the "Labor tribe" following confirmation of his death.

title.children: NSW premier's father dies days after suffering heart attack

image.altText: A colourful graphic featuring a TV icon, a teen girl, a remote, and ABC, SBS, Nine, Seven, Netflix, Disney+ and other logos.

props.synopsis: Ratings data shows young people are turning away from traditional TV in droves in favour of streaming platforms and social media. But an expert says free-to-air television still has a role, and Australia does have a choice about its media future.

title.children: In the age of streaming and social media, do we still need free-to-air TV?

image.altText: A man stands during this year's Anzac Day service in Albany. He's wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: The Liberal Party's Albany branch has endorsed Dr Thomas Brough as its candidate for next year's state election, despite a recent history of controversial public commentary.

title.children: Liberal Party preselects WA councillor who linked queer community to paedophiles

image.altText: A composite image of four fair-skinned men, three of whom are in military uniform.

props.synopsis: Captain Danniel Lyon's wife tells an inquiry into last year's fatal Taipan crash she believes it was cruel to give families hope amid the search effort.

title.children: 'Someone is going to die': Widow tells inquiry airman raised safety concerns before fatal Taipan chopper crash

image.altText: drone shot of large collection of caravans gathered around a stage on a big patch of land

props.synopsis: With pop-focused music festivals like Splendour in the Grass and Groove in the Moo calling it quits, family-friendly, smaller festivals in unique locations are thriving.

title.children: What can the Mundi Mundi Bash tell us about the future of music festivals in modern Australia?

image.altText: Nikki Davey wearing a red jumper stands behind potted flowers on a flower farm.

props.synopsis: Nikki Davey shares her approach for scheduling downtime every week, the 1 per cent rule for improvement, and the value in learning something new.

title.children: How the '1 per cent rule' has helped busy flower farmer Nikki Davey

image.altText: an outside view of a row of houses

props.synopsis: Property prices surged once again in April due the ongoing shortage of housing and rising demand. Could the rise of the YIMBY — or the "yes in my back yard" — movement be the solution to boosting the supply of affordable housing?

title.children: 'I want the best in my backyard': Why generations don't see eye to eye on boosting housing supply

image.altText: Cash being handed away by an elderly person

props.synopsis: What if the government was doing everything it could to stop thieves making off with our money, except the one thing that could really work?

title.children: Could new rules in the UK help solve Australia's scam crisis?

image.altText: Cyborg girl

props.synopsis: While artificial intelligence promises to make life easier, the technology is already affecting our mental health and understanding of reality, warns one neuroscientist.

title.children: Fear killer robots? This expert believes you should be more worried about what AI is doing to your mind

image.altText: plane on tarmac with man walking down

props.synopsis: A federal minister says a bailout for airline Bonza is "not something that the government has before us" after the carrier went into voluntary administration.

title.children: Bonza fleet grounded for days as passengers scramble for flights

image.altText: Geraldton Courthouse exterior framed by trees.

props.synopsis: Julian Brian Little faced the Geraldton Magistrates Court today charged with indecent assault over the incident after a press conference by WA Premier Roger Cook.

title.children: Man faces court over alleged indecent assault after WA Premier's press conference

image.altText: A grey short-hair cat sits on an open laptop on a home office desk.

props.synopsis: A lot of biological matter — skin cells, bacteria, hairs — are shed by people every day, many taking up residence in our home office.

title.children: The dirtiest item in your home office and how to clean it

image.altText: A calico cat standing up with its tail raised.

props.synopsis: Galena found herself at the centre of a stressful trip in an Amazon package, a feverish search, a California rescue and a tearful reunion.

title.children: Housecat who enjoys exploring cardboard boxes accidentally posted 860km in Amazon order return

image.altText: Steve Smith in Australia's ODI kit

props.synopsis: Steve Smith is left out of an Australian World Cup squad for the first time since 2012 as Australia's 15-man provisional squad is named.

title.children: 'Tailored approach': Smith axed as Australia unveils T20 World Cup squad

image.altText: An urgent care centre

props.synopsis: Staff at Colac Area Health posed as patients to make its urgent care ward look busy during a visit from the health minister. At least one ambulance was also arranged to arrive during the visit.

title.children: Regional Victorian hospital staff used ambulance and posed as patients in elaborate ruse during minister's visit

image.altText: Don Pyke speaks to the media in 2019.

props.synopsis: Essendon and Collingwood say clubs have a responsibility to show leadership in condemning violence against women, as Eagles CEO Don Pyke calls on the league to make a united and public stand.

title.children: AFL clubs back stance on gendered violence as Eagles boss Pyke highlights 'horrendous' numbers

image.altText: An aerial view shows a hydro power plant in front of a large lake.

props.synopsis: Old Argyle Diamond Mine power routes could be revived under a Kimberley mining company's hydro plan.

title.children: Under-utilised Lake Argyle hydro power offered new life

image.altText: Composite image of Kendrick Lamar and Drake performing live

props.synopsis: The internet weighs in on rap's biggest feud as Kendrick Lamar drops Euphoria — a six-minute take-down of Drake.

title.children: The best reacts to Kendrick Lamar hitting back at Drake in new six-minute diss track

image.altText: Phoebe Bridgers of boygenius, Catherine Marks, Lucy Dacus and Julien Baker of boygenius at the Resonator Awards

props.synopsis: The in-demand woman behind the desk for multi-Grammy winners boygenius tells us about dumping architecture for music, and why communication matters.

title.children: Catherine Marks is the Aussie making some of the biggest records in the world right now
